docs.lead_paragraph: Fee Payments Questioned As Insurer Inquiry Widens Three big insurance companies, Aetna, Cigna and MetLife, said that they had received subpoenas from the New York attorney general as an investigation widened into the field of employee benefits -- health, disability and group life insurance. Investigators have been concerned that payments from insurance companies to brokers for exceeding sales goals and keeping down claims costs may undermine the brokers' loyalty to the corporations that pay them fees and commissions to arrange coverage. Industry executives said similar fees were widely paid to brokers and consultants by employee benefits companies. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: A shortage of providers is threatening women's access to mammograms, a federal health advisory panel said in a report released Thursday. The number of mammography sites has dropped more than 8 percent since 2000, to a total of 8,600 around the country. In parts of Florida, three-month waits for an appointment are common, the report found. In New York City, the average wait for a first-time mammogram is more than 40 days, compared with two weeks in the late 1990's.

headline.main: Mammograms Harder to Get, Report Finds

docs.abstract: Federal health advisory panel finds that shortage of providers is threatening women's access to mammograms; notes that number of mammography sites has dropped more than 8 percent since 2000, to total of 8,000 around country; finds that in New York City, wait for mammogram is more than 40 days, compared with two weeks in late 1990's (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Stewart Request New Trial Again Martha Stewart's lawyers requested a new trial for her, arguing that lies told by a government witness prevented her from receiving fair treatment. The lawyers also asked for a hearing to determine whether any prosecutors knew that the witness was lying. It is Ms. Stewart's second attempt at overturning the verdict against her. An earlier request, in which Ms. Stewart's lawyers said a juror had lied on a screening questionnaire, was rejected last month. [Page C4.]

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines reached an agreement with its unions yesterday on a plan to cut health care benefits for 50,000 retired workers and their family members, eliminating one of the biggest issues facing the airline, which is reorganizing under court protection. United said the proposal, combined with other cuts, would save it $300 million over the next six years, or roughly $50 million a year in medical and life insurance costs. The plan will be presented to a federal bankruptcy court in Chicago for approval next week. United, a unit of UAL, is based in suburban Chicago.

headline.main: United and Its Unions Agree On Benefit Cuts for Retirees

docs.abstract: United Airlines agrees with its unions on plan to cut health care benefits for 50,000 retired workers and their family members, eliminationg big issue facing airline; proposal, combined with other cuts, will save it $300 million over next six years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals continue to have the upper hand in negotiations with health insurers, according to a new study, which found that hospitals raised prices last year by the largest margin in the decade the data have been tracked. But it is unclear how much longer hospitals will be able to continue raising prices, in light of increasing resistance by employers who pay for workers' health coverage.

headline.main: Resistance Builds as Hospital Prices Rise

docs.abstract: Study by Center for Studying Health System Change says hospitals continue to have upper hand in talks with health insurers; finds hospitals raised their overall prices by 8 percent in 2004, highest of six consecutive years of increases; National Business Group on Health says hospital costs are irresponsible; hospitals defend higher prices, saying they are often result of better care; rise in hospital spending comes after long period in which hospitals were unable to force health plans to pay much more; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed into law on Monday a fiercely contested bill that will provide $78 million in aid for doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums. But after a year and a half of political wrangling that featured doctors picketing outside the State House and lobbying patients in their examination rooms, the bill did not include the provision that insurers and the New Jersey Medical Society wanted most: a cap on pain and suffering jury awards for victims of medical malpractice.

headline.main: New Jersey Starts Fund for Malpractice Costs

docs.abstract: Gov James E McGreevey signs law that will provide $78 million in aid for New Jersey doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums; law does not cap jury awards for pain and suffering because of malpractice; will be paid for by $75 annual fee on doctors, chiropractors, dentists, optometrists and lawyers, and $3 surcharge levied against state employers for each employee; bill also limits some patient rights to sue, but doctors say limits do not go far enough (M)
